no_cooling.label: No cold air
tips: Make sure your thermostat is set to COOL and the temperature is below room temp.
Check your air filter — a clogged filter can block airflow completely.
Look at your circuit breaker panel for any tripped switches.
Make sure nothing is blocking your outdoor unit (debris, leaves, snow).
no_cooling.seasonal_winter: If it's cold outside, your AC has a low-ambient lockout and won't run below a certain temperature — that's normal and protects the equipment.
no_cooling.seasonal_summer: During heat waves, most AC systems can only cool about 15-20°F below the outdoor temp. If it's 100°F out, 80°F inside may be all your system can manage.

no_heat.label: No heat
tips: Check that your thermostat is set to HEAT and above room temperature.
If you have a furnace, check whether the pilot light is on (older models).
Make sure your air filter isn't clogged — this is one of the most common causes.
Check your breaker panel for any tripped switches.
no_heat.seasonal_winter: In freezing weather, keep your home above 55°F even when you're away to prevent frozen pipes. Opening cabinet doors under sinks helps warm air circulate around pipes.

strange_noise.label: Strange noises
tips: Banging or clanking — usually a loose or broken part inside the unit.
Squealing or screeching — often a belt or motor bearing that needs attention.
Buzzing — may be an electrical component or a failing contactor.
Rattling — could be a loose panel, screw, or something in the ductwork.

leaking.label: Leaking or water
tips: Clogged condensate drain line — this is the most common cause and usually a straightforward fix.
Frozen evaporator coil — turn the system off and let it thaw, then check your filter.
Cracked or rusted drain pan — especially common in units over 10 years old.
If there's a lot of water, turn the system off to prevent further damage to your home.

wont_start.label: Won't turn on
tips: Check your thermostat — make sure it's powered on and batteries aren't dead.
Look at your circuit breaker panel for any tripped breakers.
Check the furnace/AC power switch (usually looks like a light switch near the unit).
If you have an outdoor unit, make sure nothing is blocking or covering it.

short_cycling.label: Turns on/off quickly
tips: This is called 'short cycling' and it puts a lot of stress on the equipment.
Check your air filter first — a clogged filter is the number one cause.
Make sure your thermostat isn't near a heat source like a sunny window or vent.
If the filter is clean, it could be a refrigerant or sizing issue that needs professional attention.

weak_airflow.label: Weak airflow
tips: Check your air filter — this is the most common cause of reduced airflow.
Make sure all vents and registers throughout your home are open and unblocked.
Listen for the blower fan — if it's not running, the motor may need attention.
Leaks or blockages in ductwork can also reduce flow and need professional inspection.

bad_smell.label: Strange smell
tips: Musty or moldy smell — likely mold or mildew on the evaporator coil or in ductwork.
Burning smell — turn the system off immediately and check near the unit for any burning odors.
Rotten egg smell — this could indicate a gas leak. Leave the house immediately and call your gas company, then call us.
Dusty smell when first turning on for the season — usually normal and should clear within an hour.

safety_tips.gas_smell: Important: If you smell rotten eggs or gas, leave your home immediately. Don't flip any switches. Call 911 or your gas company from outside, then give us a call.
safety_tips.no_heat_winter: While you wait: use space heaters safely (keep them 3 feet from anything flammable), never use your oven or stove to heat your home, and keep interior doors open to help circulate whatever warmth is there.
safety_tips.no_cooling_summer: While you wait: close blinds and curtains on sun-facing windows, use fans to circulate air, stay hydrated, and try not to use your oven — it adds a lot of heat to your home.
safety_tips.electrical: If you see sparks, smell burning from the unit, or hear loud popping sounds, turn your system off at the breaker immediately. Don't try to restart it — let a technician take a look.
safety_tips.water_damage: If there's significant water, turn the system off and move any electronics or valuables away from the area. Towels and a bucket can help contain things until we get there.
safety_tips.general: While you're waiting for your technician: make sure the area around your indoor and outdoor units is clear and accessible. If you have pets, it helps to keep them in another room when the tech arrives.
